newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK stocks end up ahead of holiday on rate outlook.
newsitem.headline: HK stocks end up ahead of holiday on rate outlook.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks ended higher ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday, buoyed by expectations of a steady, near-term interest rate outlook, brokers said.
The Hang Seng Index jumped 112.07 points, or 0.83 percent, to close Wednesday's session at 13,660.50.
"I believe it has a lot to do with the recovery in the U.S. bond market," said Vickers Ballas director of research Andrew Fernow. "People are not so worried about interest rates."
The U.S. Federal Reserve will end a two-day policy setting meeting later on Wednesday and is widely expected to leave interest rates unchanged.
Analysts said investors were already discounting the news. They will be unable to react on Thursday and Friday since the market will be closed for the Lunar New Year.
Peter Lai, associate director at OCBC Securities, said the Hang Seng Index could test 14,000 points next week if rates remain unchanged.
"The fundamentals are very strong. After Chinese New Year, people will begin to put energy into the market," he said.
Wednesday's turnover rose to HK$7.25 billion compared with HK$6.74 billion on Tuesday, boosted by trade in China Eastern Airlines which made its market debut on Wednesday.
The stock opened at HK$1.50 compared with an issue price of HK$1.38 but closed at HK$1.45 on heavy volume of 366 million shares. It is the first overseas listing of a Chinese airline.
"I think that airlines suffer from a lot of risks that other stocks don't have, particularly in China," said Fernow.

"The Chinese aviation industry is very heavily regulated. I am not that confident that this particular company can produce a solid performance over the long term. It has competition on the international routes and is also burdened with a lot of debt."
Analysts also pointed to China's move to cut fares for foreigners in 1997.
The China Daily newspaper said on Tuesday that Chinese aviation authorities have slashed domestic air fares for foreigners travelling in China to try to boost tourism.
The banking sector made strong gains on Wednesday with HSBC Holdings finishing at HK$184.00, up HK$2.00, and Hang Seng Bank climbing HK$1.75 to HK$93.25.
Conglomerates were also buoyant. Hutchison rose HK$0.50 to HK$59.75 and Wheelock gained HK$0.40 to HK$21.60.
In the property sector, Sun Hung Kai Properties rose HK$0.75 to HK$93.00 and Henderson Land gained HK$0.75 to HK$73.50.
